ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: attending workshops, teach-ins, book talks, etc
A mix of virtual events and discussions
This 0.5 credit was a series of virtual lectures and workshops related to ER&M held throughout the semester.
ER&M 100 was a workshop series that combined lectures, methods workshops, guest speakers, an open house, etc.
There was no class but rather lectures and presentations we chose to attend.
There was variation in the formats offered, but they were all live events we could watch.
Weekly lectures and workshops.
Attendance of different online seminars hosted through a few media: zoom, instagram live, etc
attend virtual events sponsored/highlighted by ERM department throughout the semester (at least 4).
The learning took the form of both live and recorded virtual seminars/webinars.
Talks with a variety of interesting speakers
multiple live speaker events, lectures, and workshops
We attended guest lectures and varying ER&M events on campus.
Workshops
Series of Seminars

This workshop gave us access to live lectures, webinars, and virtual panels. There were also opportunities to attend talks held by librarians about developing research skills and professors about methodology in their particular fields.
We just attended our own events!

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned more about the field of ethnic studies
I was exposed to a wide array of topics and individuals related to my major that I would have not gotten the opportunity to otherwise.
I got the opportunity to learn from people, scholars, professors, authors, etc. on various different topics as well as interact a bit with the ER&M community during the ER&M open house.
The lectures were very engaging.
There was such a variety in what was offered, so the different events all offered different knowledge and insights , but they were all helpful for broadening my perspective as an ER&M student.
An introduction to various ER&M classes and discussions.
Introduction to prominent scholars and new realms of scholarly activity that I did not know existed.
I was able to survey a number of areas of my major with speakers who talked about issues that are important to me.
ERM 100 is an excellent course, consisting of guest speaking events and community bonding.
I was able to stay connected with the ER&M community and attend varying ER&M events.
I experienced a range of opinions, current topics, and methodical approaches to topics related to ER&M.

The talks I chose to attend did a good job of accompanying the topics being covered in my other seminars and lectures this semester, as well as expanding upon topics I was personally interested in. As per the course requirements, I went to four events. I got to hear directly from the author of "Solitary," Albert Woodfox, who argued for the importance of literacy and education as tools for self-empowerment and resistance. Professor Grace Kao analyzed the growing global influence of K-POP by tracing BTS's rise to fame. I gained more insight into the geopolitical links between immigration and imprisonment after hearing from former detainees invited by the Migrant Justice Initiative. Finally, in recognizing the impending 20th anniversary of 9/11, I was introduced to experimental films that unpacked the experience of Muslims in America following the tragedy.
A great way to learn more about ER&M and attend events for credit
This workshop allowed me to connect with other students in my department that I otherwise would not have.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: strengths: easy half credit, community building
Great course!
I loved being able to attend events that were most interesting to you and engaging with the ER&M community in a lowstakes way. It did not have any weaknesses.

The strengths of the course is that it provides multiple opportunities per week to attend these lectures, workshops, events, etc. and hear and learn about different topics and disciplines! This course could be improved by having more ER&M community oriented events.
The strength of this course is that we are given the freedom to chose what seminars interest us.
Sometimes the webinars or lectures we could attend were discussing something from a class, like a book or something specific they were learning, so it was difficult to follow or understand.
A calendar that lists events further in advance.
Amazing course to build community!
The talks, workshops, and performances I went to were all very interesting and engaging! However, I would love more interaction among ER&M students along with attending events.
It was amazing!

This course offers access to events covering a wide variety of topics; with this structure, surely every student could find a couple that interest them. The speakers are very engaging, and beyond the opportunity to ask questions during the forum that normally concludes the second half of the webinars/panels/workshops, students are commonly provided with their contact information should they want to continue the conversation with the speakers more. While I appreciated the weekly reminders for upcoming events, I think it would be helpful to have a more comprehensive list or calendar with all the events so we could plan ahead to attend specific events, rather than squeeze them into our weekly schedule.
The strengths include the fact that it recognized the central role that community serves in a student's education.
Lots of great, engaging speakers!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the virtual format and sheer amount of events that qualified made it accessible and easy to complete the requirements
The course itself was made in order to build community in this time -- no improvements at all!
The flexibility was wonderful, much appreciated.
The virtual format of the events succeeded.
The WhatsApp chat helped and all the emails helped me stay on track.
All succeeded.
Everything succeeded!
It offered lots of flexibility which was necessary for a year like this.
Everything was remote, so in regards to safety and accessibility, this course was rather successful.
I would love it if there were more recorded lectures available
The live Q&A sessions were extremely informative and engaging.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! its an easy half credit
Yes!
Yes - definitely! It was amazing to get this extra 0.5 credits during this difficult semester for just attending a minimum number of ER&M events and workshops.
Yes!!!
Yes, it was refreshing and helpful.
Yes, it is a good opportunity to stay in the loop and attend events, lectures, workshops, etc. that we normally would have attended during a normal, non-virtual, non-COVID-19 impacted semester.
Yes, because it encourages students to pursue what they would like and increase their knowledge.
Yes! Its a great opportunity to supplement our learning in ER&am courses without a big commitment.
Yes, if you are interested in ER&M, but you'll be fine if you don't take it.
Yes, as a fifth or sixth course.
Yes!
Yes!
Yes!!!
Yes!
Yes! Especially if youre an ER&M major.

Yes, it's a great way to stay connected to the ER&M community! While the virtual events are interesting to supplement your learning, I really appreciate the attempt to bring students and faculty closer through the WhatsApp group chat, especially during all the turbulence of 2020. This course is also a great way to earn half a credit for those who need it, as the requirements are very reasonable even if you already have an intense workload from other courses.
Yes! Connecting with the ER&M community can make all the difference in a student's educational path -- especially during this pandemic.
Yes! It was not so high stakes and just a really great atmosphere for learning and sharing.
Yes!
